sourceDesc.p: his is the feature-file for the Progressive markers (prefix – auxiliaries) (e.g. gaʕad- , ʕam- ).

revisionDesc.change: updating references to Zotero IDs via update-bibl-refs.xsl

item.label: qēʔəd, gāʕid, gāʕda, gāʕdä, gāʕdīn, kāʕid, gāʕəd, ǧāʕid

cit.quote: How much is he paying you?

wib:featureValueObservation.note: "Unlike many of the dialects in Syria however, ʕa- is also found with some frequency in the data. Presumably a contraction from ǧaʕad. The sedentary continuous particle is typically ʕam." (Pickett 2005:245)

"Unlike many of the dialects in Syria however, ʕa- is also found with some frequency in the data. Presumably a contraction from ǧaʕad. The sedentary continuous particle is typically ʕam." (Pickett 2005:245)

"Unlike many of the dialects in Syria however, ʕa- is also found with some frequency in the data. Presumably a contraction from ǧaʕad. The sedentary continuous particle is typically ʕam." (Pickett 2005:245)

cit.quote: She is making bread on the tannur oven

wib:featureValueObservation.note: It is not invariable but rather inflects with gender and number (Younes and Herin 2013:50)

According to the author, this form is a "new" one that has entered the dialect as a result of contact with sedentary speakers from the neighboring areas who use ʕam- and ʕan- (Younes and Herin 2013:51)

cit.quote: She is telling her father the story

wib:featureValueObservation.note: It is the only progressive marker in this dialect and it is invariable (Younes 2014:378)

cit.quote: lamma ʔiǧa huṃṃa gāʕdīn yidfunu bī-ha
when he arrived they were buring her
bi-tḏakar aḥda barḏ̣o qiṣṣa min al-qiṣṣaṣ

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Bi- is used only once as a progressive marker in the corpus
ʕam is also used
Fink (2017:104) notes that the ū in the 1st Person Singular normally is lost (kīšrab - I am drinking.).

cit.quote: w anā banṣaḥ kull ʔinsān ʔinnu ywaddī ʔibnu l-il-masǧid
I am advising everyone to take his son regularly to the mosque.

wib:featureValueObservation.note: less frequently used
less frequently used
According to Abu Nahleh (1985:45) some speakers add the inderect object morpheme such as li (see example).
Maltese orthography: qed niekol
Maltese orthography: qiegħda nikteb
Maltese orthography: qiegħed nitkellem
Maltese orthography: qegħdin nsajru

cit.quote: gāʕid yimrax-ni u abūy yirūḥ il-manāma
He kept on massaging me while my father went off to Manāma
gāʕid yimrax-ni u abūy yirūḥ il-manāma
He kept on massaging me while my father went off to Manāma
kil mā bēn ṯalāṯat šuhūr d-yišrab-ha
He would drink it over a period of three months

wib:featureValueObservation.note: This is used by village dialects of the Baḥārna
In Tripoli Arabic gāʕid has the function of 'still'
Verb modifier present

entry includes Awlad Azzaz in the Sohag governorate

cit.quote: Oh Ḏ̣āhir, why are you hitting ...the soldiers?

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Drop/Woidich mention the particle tann for continuity (2007:75)
Hagège (1973:48) lists "ga:'iT" as a progressive marker in Chadian Arabic
Verb modifier present
Active participles can also be used to express progressive actions

cit.quote: b-al-lēl yismaʕ aǧ-ǧimal ǧaʕad yhaddir b-al-baʕar.
At night he heared the camel giving a grunt to the other camels.

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Identical marker is used for the habitual aspect.
Also used as habituel and indicative marker

In its predicative uses the active participle (inflected for masc., fem., and pl.) expresses an ongoing process: qaʿdat… ʿiša mʿa ixwaha ‘she used to stay… living with her brothers’. When combined with ra- it keeps the same function and meaning and the particle plays the role of a copula: ra-ni xaddəm ‘I am busy working’(EALL: Algiers Arabic).
The prefix ka- is used for habituel and durative meaning, also the prefix la- is found, only in women's speech, which is conjugated (p.111)
Also used as habituel marker
also as habituel marker, less frequent than ta-
also as habituel marker, more frequent than ka-
1st and 2nd person use ti and 3rd person use ta, but all in all not prevalent
also used as indicative marker and habituel
also used as indicative marker and habituel
But may be indicated with active participle huwwä tāləʕ əlkədyä 'he is going up the mountain’
In a similar meaning, the participles qāʿid and wōquf may be used (Fischer 1961:256), as well as ġōdi, e.g. miyoġdi ġōdi ‘he was going on’ (Dereli 1997:85).
also used as indicative and habitual marker
